description:
Commuter trains are renowned for potentially being cramped and crowded, but they don’t have to be that way. Tiny adjustments to a commuter train’s design – from the width of the doors to the position of the handholds – can have huge impacts on the speed that passengers can get on and off, and can make or break the economics of a train service. WSJ sits down with train manufacturer Alstom to discover what a perfected commuter train could look like.

#Train #Subway #Shorts
title: What Does It Take to Perfect the Commuter Train?

description:
Meta AI, Google Gemini, OpenAI ChatGPT and Microsoft Copilot now have eerily human voices. WSJ’s Joanna Stern strapped the AI bots to a tripod and took them to a cabin in the woods to test their skills as helpers—and as friends.

Chapters:
0:00 Human-sounding AI 
1:10 The voice setup
2:02 Testing bots as helpers 
4:01 Testing bots as friends
6:16 Takeaways

Tech Things With Joanna Stern
Everything is now a tech thing. In creative and humorous videos, WSJ senior personal tech columnist Joanna Stern explains and reviews the products, services and trends that are changing our world.

#AI #Chatbot #WSJ
title: I Spent 24 Hours in the Woods With Talking AI Chatbots | WSJ
